answers.answer: hi not a doctor but.......with all the automimmnune diseases in your family (also in my family, graves, hashimoto, diabetes and lupus)  I would start with an endocrinologist.  As for the pain and numbing thru leg a good place to start would eihter be a neurogist or orthopedic surgeon who specializes almost in nerves the way a neuro does, the orthopedic also specializes in joints.good luck!!!!!!
Your regular Dr. can run a complete autoimmune panel. Or you can see a rheumatologist, if your reg. Dr. doesn't know what to do.

Where is you hip pain? The hip joint is midway on the leg where the leg crease is.  You will feel a little indentation there.  That is your hip joint.  If the pain is there, then it is your hip.  If the pain is on the outside of the leg, there is a bursa, or air space there.  It can become inflammed and be very painful.  Injections of steriods will get rid of it.  See an orthopedist for xrays.

question: Back in December I started having a slight pain in my left hip.  I thought it was probably due to the cold weather. It was no big deal.  Then about a month ago I was working in my yard and did some heavy lifting that I probably shouldn't have done.  Since that day I have had severe pain in my left hip.  It hurts mostly when I get up after sitting for a while.  The pain is really severe for about 10 steps then the pain decreases to just mild pain.  It hurts to bear any weight on it also.  It's been a good 4 weeks and I keep expecting the pain to subside but it seems to be getting worse.  I also have back pain which I've had for about 4 or 5 years.  I have muscle spasms in the left side of my back and also burning pain in the middle of my back.  I have some sciatica symptoms but not enough to complain about.  I've also noticed that I have a numb spot on the bottom of my left foot.  In the past 4 or 5 years I have also had chronic muscle pain and fatigue which my doctor told me was probably Fibro.  I take 50 miligrams of Elavil a day and that has pretty much taken away those 2 symptoms by probably 70 or 80 percent.  Almost all of the living women on my dad's side of the family have been diagnosed with some sort of auto-immune disorder (R.A., Lupus,M.S., Thyroid disease), including my sister.  I guess I'm just really looking for someone to point me in the right direction as to what type of doctor I need to see.  Any information would be helpful.
